SUMMARY: Americans are poised to bet a record amount on Sunday's big game. Kansas and California are among the dozen states that have not yet legalized sports betting since the national ban was lifted in 2018.

TITLE: Charges dropped against Ohio pastor who housed homeless people at his church
SUMMARY: Chris Avell, a pastor from Bryan, Ohio, faced charges after turning his church into a quasi-homeless shelter, partly in response to the city's housing shortage.

TITLE: K-12 students learned a lot last year, but they're still missing too much school
SUMMARY: Families will play an essential role in getting students back on track, researchers say. But it's going to take a "culture" shift around the importance of being in school.

TITLE: Coronavirus FAQ: I'm immunocompromised. Will pills, gargles and sprays fend off COVID?
SUMMARY: People who are immunocompromised continue to worry about COVID. A raft of products promise protection. Is there any evidence they can protect from infection or lessen severity of disease?

TITLE: New DOJ watchdog report details FBI officials' misconduct with foreign prostitutes
SUMMARY: It paints a picture of FBI employees who repeatedly engaged in activities that violated Justice Department and FBI policies, and exposed them to possible extortion and blackmail.

TITLE: As one Pakistani ex-PM looks to form a coalition, another releases an AI video speech
SUMMARY: The party of Pakistan's jailed former prime minister, Imran Khan, used artificial intelligence to post an online post-election speech by Khan.

TITLE: Hawaii's high court cites 'The Wire' in its ruling on gun rights
SUMMARY: It says a man can be prosecuted for carrying a gun in public without a permit citing "The Wire" and invokes the "spirit of Aloha" in  rebuke of a U.S. Supreme Court decision that expanded gun rights.

TITLE: Former Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan is running for the U.S. Senate
SUMMARY: The move gives Republicans a prominent candidate who is well-positioned to run a competitive campaign for the GOP in a state that hasn't had a Republican U.S. senator in 37 years.

TITLE: Some say the Las Vegas Super Bowl is rigged. And not because of Taylor Swift
SUMMARY: When Allegiant Stadium in Las Vegas was built, a worker said he buried a Chiefs Kingdom flag in the field. Kansas City has never lost a game there, sparking a controversial conspiracy theory.

TITLE: Biden's rough week highlights his biggest vulnerability — one he can't change
SUMMARY: President Biden's most glaring vulnerability in his reelection campaign is his age, and it was front and center this week in a special counsel report about his handling of classified documents.

TITLE: Special counsel's report on classified documents has echoes of the 2016 election
SUMMARY: For people who were involved with Hillary Clinton's failed 2016 presidential campaign, the echoes of then-FBI Director James Comey's press conference on July 5, 2016, are hard to miss.

TITLE: Republicans see Latino voters in Nevada as key to retaking the White House in 2024
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump has pretty sharp rhetoric around immigration. At the same time, he is trying to reach a potentially powerful voting bloc in pivtal swing states: Latinos.

TITLE: Vets' jewelry company feels the 'Swift effect' after the singer wore diamond bracelet
SUMMARY: A year ago NPR talked with two former U.S. Army Rangers who started a jewelry company. After Taylor Swift wore one of their bracelets at a football game, their sales jumped 2,000%.

TITLE: We asked. You answered. Here are your secrets to healthy aging
SUMMARY: NPR asked our audiences to share their hard-won wisdom. We heard from more than 1,000 people, aged 16 to 103! Here's a roundup of your best advice for thriving as you age.

TITLE: Cheap, plentiful and devastating: The synthetic drug kush is walloping Sierra Leone
SUMMARY: Kush, a synthetic cannabinoid, is spreading quickly for the promise of a stress-relieving high. But what's the impact on users — and Sierra Leonean society? And how are the authorities responding?

TITLE: Super Bowl 2024: How to watch the Chiefs v. 49ers
SUMMARY: The Kansas City Chiefs will play the San Francisco 49ers in Las Vegas for Super Bowl 58 on Sunday. Here's what you need to know going into the big game.

TITLE: A tiny robot on the space station will simulate remote-controlled surgery up there
SUMMARY: A robotic assistant recently arrived at the International Space Station to perform a simulated surgery that will be controlled by a surgeon 250 miles away on Earth.

TITLE: Israel says it discovered tunnels under U.N. agency's Gaza headquarters
SUMMARY: The Israeli military said it discovered a network of tunnels under the UNRWA headquarters in Gaza City. UNRWA said it did not know what was underneath its headquarters.

TITLE: High profile women stand out on the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame shortlist
SUMMARY: Mariah Carey, Cher, Sinéad O'Connor, Mary J. Blige and Sade are on the latest inductee shortlist. It's notable for an institution long focused on white male artists.

TITLE: Israeli military operation in Rafah 'cannot proceed,' U.S. ambassador to the U.N. says
SUMMARY: U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. Linda Thomas-Greenfield told NPR that under the current conditions, Israeli military operations in Rafah would "dramatically exacerbate the humanitarian emergency."

TITLE: Wisconsin Republican Rep. Mike Gallagher says he won't run for reelection
SUMMARY: Rep. Mike Gallagher, a key Republican congressman who has spearheaded House pushback against the Chinese government, announced Saturday that he won't run for a fifth term.

TITLE: Trump says he'd 'encourage' Russia to attack NATO allies who don't pay their bills
SUMMARY: Republican front-runner Donald Trump said Saturday that, as president, he warned NATO allies that he "would encourage" Russia "to do whatever the hell they want" to countries that are "delinquent".

TITLE: CEO of major Nigerian bank killed in helicopter crash in California's Mojave Desert
SUMMARY: The CEO of one of Nigeria's largest banks was killed Friday along with his wife and son when a helicopter they were riding in crashed near Interstate 15 in Southern California's Mojave Desert.

TITLE: Social isolation takes a toll on a rising number of South Korea's young adults
SUMMARY: A growing number of South Korea's young adults are isolating themselves from society, raising questions about the state of youths in a country known for cutthroat competition and pressure to conform.

TITLE: Jeff Bezos sells nearly 12 million Amazon shares worth at least $2 billion
SUMMARY: Jeff Bezos filed a statement with federal regulators indicating his sale of nearly 12 million shares of Amazon stock worth more than $2 billion.

TITLE: Jill Biden wonders whether special counsel used son's death to score political points
SUMMARY: "Joe is 81... but he's 81 doing more in an hour than most people do in a day. Joe has wisdom, empathy, and vision," Jill Biden wrote in an email to donors. "His age... is an incredible asset."

TITLE: Debate simmers over when doctors should declare brain death
SUMMARY: Bioethicists, doctors and lawyers are weighing whether to redefine how someone should be declared dead. A change in criteria for brain death could have wide-ranging implications for patients' care.

TITLE: Trump says he wouldn't defend NATO allies from Russia if they're 'delinquent'
SUMMARY: The Republican front-runner said that, as president, he warned NATO allies that he "would encourage" Russia "to do whatever the hell they want" to countries that don't meet their spending commitments.

TITLE: A nor'easter is coming for the Northeast, from Pennsylvania to Maine
SUMMARY: The storm is forecast to bring snow, rain and gusty winds across the northeast leading up to Valentine's Day. Up to a foot of snow is expected in some places.

TITLE: Israeli military operation in Rafah 'cannot proceed,' U.S. ambassador to the UN says
SUMMARY: U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. Linda Thomas-Greenfield told NPR that under the current conditions, Israeli military operations in Rafah would "dramatically exacerbate the humanitarian emergency."

TITLE: Biden tells Netanyahu to 'not proceed' in Rafah without plan to protect civilians
SUMMARY: This is the first time Biden has publicly cautioned Israel against its planned operation in Rafah.

TITLE: Super Bowl 2024: The Kansas City Chiefs v. San Francisco 49ers
SUMMARY: The Kansas City Chiefs face off against the San Francisco 49ers in Las Vegas for Super Bowl 58. Here's what you need to know for the big game.

TITLE: Will the Chiefs or the 49ers win the Super Bowl? The animal kingdom weighs in
SUMMARY: Animals at zoos and shelters across the U.S. are making their predictions for which team will win Super Bowl 58.

TITLE: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin is hospitalized again, weeks after cancer treatment
SUMMARY: The Sunday afternoon announcement came just weeks after Austin was diagnosed with prostate cancer in December and hospitalized for a procedure.

TITLE: Trump slams Swift, prompting other politicians to come out as Swifties
SUMMARY: Donald Trump said on social media that copyright legislation he signed while president had made Swift "so much money," arguing it would be "disloyal" of her to endorse Biden as many are speculating.

TITLE: High school football players, survivors of Maui wildfires, are honored at Super Bowl
SUMMARY: Four players and three coaches from Lahainaluna High School met pro NFL stars on the turf to serve as honorary captains during the pre-game coin toss.

TITLE: Super Bowl 2024 updates: The commercials, cameos, halftime show and more
SUMMARY: The Kansas City Chiefs face off against the San Francisco 49ers in Las Vegas for Super Bowl 58. Here's what you need to know for the big game.

TITLE: The story behind Carl Weathers' posthumous Super Bowl ad
SUMMARY: Carl Weathers, the NFL player-turned-actor, made a posthumous cameo in a Super Bowl ad for the online gambling company FanDuel. The company reworked it after he died earlier this month.

TITLE: Beyoncé releases two new songs during the Super Bowl, teasing more to come
SUMMARY: Beyoncé teased, confirmed and dropped new music in the span of less than an hour during Sunday's Super Bowl. She released two songs, Texas Hold 'Em" and "16 carriages," promising more in March.

TITLE: Kelvin Kiptum, men's marathon world record holder, dies in a car crash
SUMMARY: World Athletics confirmed the 24-year-old died in his native Kenya alongside his coach, Gervais Hakizimana.

TITLE: The Kansas City Chiefs win back-to-back Super Bowls
SUMMARY: Kansas City won 25-22 in overtime, securing back-to-back championships. It is their third in five years.

TITLE: The Israeli military says it has rescued 2 hostages from captivity in Gaza
SUMMARY: Israeli military strikes on Rafah, Gaza were part of an operation to rescue two Israeli hostages taken by Hamas on Oct. 7. There were initial reports that Palestinians were killed in the strikes.

TITLE: Weight-loss drugs aren't a magic bullet. Lifestyle changes are key to lasting health
SUMMARY: A doctor argues that the current focus on fighting obesity with drugs like Ozempic ignores the bigger picture: We need a medical system and society that support healthy life habits.

TITLE: Violent crime is dropping fast in the U.S. — even if Americans don't believe it
SUMMARY: In 2020, the United States experienced one of its most dangerous years in decades. But in 2023, crime in America looked very different. That change may have gone unnoticed.

TITLE: Super Bowl ads played it safe, but there were still some winners
SUMMARY: Celebrities from Beyoncé to Arnold Schwarzenegger sold products with a wink.

TITLE: Mummified monkey remains were found in luggage at Boston's airport
SUMMARY: A traveler returning from the Democratic Republic of Congo attempted to sneak in the mummified remains of four monkeys.

TITLE: As hunger stalks Gaza, humanitarian aid is politicized in Israel
SUMMARY: Aid organizations warn pockets of people in Gaza are already starving. But, in Israel, a small movement of protesters have been trying to block aid trucks from entering the Gaza Strip.

TITLE: Youth with autism are more likely to be arrested. A Nevada judge wants to remedy that
SUMMARY: Judge Sunny Bailey started a specialty court program in 2018 called DAAY Court or the detention alternative for autistic youth treatment. "It'll help other people like me," says one autistic teen."

TITLE: Flight attendants don't earn their hourly pay until aircraft doors close. Here's why
SUMMARY: Arguing that their jobs have become more onerous, flight attendants want to be better compensated for time on the ground, including during boarding.

TITLE: A rescue ship saved them from the sea. Now these migrants find a tough road in Europe
SUMMARY: Thousands of migrants have drowned while trying to cross the Mediterranean Sea from North Africa to Europe. The dangerous journey does not deter many more from the risky crossing.

TITLE: At 79, she reached her goal to visit every country in the world
SUMMARY: Luisa Yu spent the past five decades plotting to see all 193 U.N.-recognized countries. To realize her dream, she faced numerous visa hurdles and, later in life, made a career change.

TITLE: Cocoa prices spiked to an all-time high right before Valentine's Day
SUMMARY: Chocolate lovers won't see a sudden price spike for Valentine's Day — because the cost already has been rising for months. Extreme weather is largely to blame.

TITLE: Israel rescues 2 hostages, but Gaza officials say dozens were killed in the operation
SUMMARY: Israeli military strikes in Rafah were part of an operation to rescue two Israeli hostages taken by Hamas on Oct. 7. There were initial reports that at least 50 Palestinians were killed in the raid.

TITLE: NATO leader criticizes Trump's comments. Israel frees two hostages in Rafah operation
SUMMARY: NATO chief criticizes Trump after he threatened to abandon NATO allies. Israel's military says it rescued 2 hostages in Gaza.

TITLE: An account from the frontline of 'the largest displacement of children on the planet'
SUMMARY: James Elder is a spokesperson for UNICEF — the U.N. agency that provides humanitarian aid to children — and has been visiting the areas on the border of Sudan and Chad.

TITLE: 'The voice we woke up to': Bob Edwards, longtime 'Morning Edition' host, dies at 76
SUMMARY: Edwards, a consummate newsman, hosted NPR's morning show for more than two decades. "He sort of set the tone and the bar for all of us," says one former NPR executive.

TITLE: As Gaza strains under a food crisis, some Israeli protesters are trying to block aid
SUMMARY: Aid organizations warn pockets of people in Gaza are already starving. But, in Israel, a small movement of protesters have been trying to block aid trucks from entering the Gaza Strip.

TITLE: Photos: Israel targets Rafah as dissent against Hamas grows in Gaza
SUMMARY: This past week, Israel rejected a proposed cease-fire, the U.S. ambassador to the U.N. announced that Israel has a obligation to keep civilians safe as military strikes expand into southern Gaza.

TITLE: A nor'easter could drop several inches of snow on New York City, New England
SUMMARY: Parts of New York City could see at least 6 inches of snow, while somewhere between 8 inches to a foot could fall in Boston. Public schools in both cities will be closed Tuesday.

TITLE: Republicans play clean up on aisle Trump after former president's NATO comments
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump's anecdote about encouraging Russian aggression towards some NATO countries is a sign of his foreign policy plans if elected – or maybe it's not.

TITLE: RFK Jr. apologizes to his family for Super Bowl ad invoking JFK
SUMMARY: Longshot candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. issued an apology to the Kennedy family Sunday night after his super PAC ran an ad repurposing one from former President John F. Kennedy's 1960 campaign.

TITLE: Yet another FAFSA problem: non-citizens can't fill it out
SUMMARY: Parents who aren't citizens aren't able to complete the new version of the widely used financial-aid form, adding another barrier to families struggling with the college admissions process.

TITLE: Trump appeals immunity ruling to the Supreme Court
SUMMARY: Last week, three judges on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit rejected Trump's bid for blanket immunity over acts he allegedly committed while in the White House.

TITLE: A court orders Netherlands to halt fighter jet part exports to Israel over Gaza war
SUMMARY: The court said there is a "clear risk that Israel's F-35 fighter jets might be used in the commission of serious violations of international humanitarian law."

TITLE: Republicans play cleanup on aisle Trump after former president's NATO comments
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump's anecdote about encouraging Russian aggression toward some NATO countries is a sign of his foreign policy plans if elected — or maybe it's not.

TITLE: Across the world, migrating animal populations are dwindling. Here's why
SUMMARY: In a landmark UN study, researchers found nearly half of the world's threatened migratory species have declining populations. More than a fifth of the assessed animals face extinction.

TITLE: Mardi Gras beads in New Orleans are creating an environmental concern
SUMMARY: Despite a daily cleanup that leaves the post-parade landscape remarkably clean, uncaught beads dangle from tree limbs like Spanish moss and get ground into the mud under the feet of passers-by.

TITLE: The 2024 Super Bowl becomes the most watched NFL championship in history
SUMMARY: About 123 million people tuned in across platforms, including CBS, Paramount+, Univision and Nickelodeon. The Kansas City Chiefs defeated the San Francisco 49ers in a game that went to overtime.

TITLE: Shots can be scary and painful for kids. One doctor has a plan to end needle phobia
SUMMARY: Research suggests the biggest source of pain for children in the health care system is needles. One California doctor says the fear of needles is a serious problem, but proposes some simple solutions.

TITLE: Hospitals are fighting a Medicare payment fix that would save tax dollars
SUMMARY: Medicare pays hospitals about double what it pays other providers for the same services. The hospital lobby is fighting hard to make sure a switch to "site-neutral payments" doesn't become law.

TITLE: Skip candy this Valentine's Day. Here are some healthier options
SUMMARY: Most of the candy that you see on grocery store shelves is processed and high in sugar. Consider a healthier alternative for your loved one this year.

TITLE: With Western military aid increasingly uncertain, Ukraine builds its own weapons
SUMMARY: Ukraine's domestic arms manufacturers bristle at the notion the country relies entirely on military aid from the U.S. and Europe. The country's weapons development and production, they say, is robust.

TITLE: How Hollywood art directors are working to keep their sets out of the landfill
SUMMARY: Sets are often discarded after productions, with thousands of tons of materials going into dumpsters each year. Now art directors and their allies are pushing for a more sustainable approach.

TITLE: Large majorities of Americans say antisemitism is a serious problem
SUMMARY: A report from the American Jewish Committee finds that 94% of American Jews say antisemitism is a "very serious" or "somewhat serious" problem in the U.S. That's up significantly from a year ago.

TITLE: Jon Stewart's 'Daily Show' return is so smooth, it's like he never left
SUMMARY: Stewart eased back into the host's chair Monday night without missing a beat, firing off jokes with a familiar style that felt like he had left just a few weeks ago, rather than in 2015.

TITLE: Border security dominates in New York special election to replace Rep. Santos
SUMMARY: Border politics have dominated the special election to replace expelled former Rep. George Santos in a critical swing district in New York.

TITLE: Senate advances military aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan
SUMMARY: The measure, which would provide $95 billion in military aid, has little hope of seeing a vote in the House where hard-line Republicans oppose the measure.

TITLE: 3 things you should know about Indonesia's presidential elections
SUMMARY: The nation's younger voters may decide whether the world's third-largest democracy maintains economic growth and political reform or slides backward to the authoritarian politics of a generation ago.

TITLE: New Gaza cease-fire talks to begin in Cairo; Senate passes foreign aid bill
SUMMARY: Officials begin new efforts to work out a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas. A bipartisan Senate majority passed a $95 billion foreign aid package for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan.

TITLE: Mediators are in Cairo working to secure a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas
SUMMARY: The talks come as Israel signals it may soon launch an invasion of Rafah, in the south of the Gaza Strip. The talks were expected to center on a plan that would pause the fighting for up to six weeks.

TITLE: A rapidly moving winter storm disrupts travel and closes schools in the Northeast
SUMMARY: The nor'easter struck the Northeast on Monday evening and is pushing east. Heavy snow and strong winds have disrupted travel and affected millions of residents with road and school closures.

TITLE: Grover the Muppet becomes a journalist, shining a light on the plight of the industry
SUMMARY: "As a news reporter ... I am confident to report that you are so special and amazing," Grover tweeted. Some responded with jokes about him getting laid off, a common occurrence in today's media world.

TITLE: A landslide in Turkey has trapped 9 gold mine workers
SUMMARY: Nine mine workers were trapped underground after a landslide at a gold mine in Turkey's eastern Anatolia region.

TITLE: Yes, a lot of people watched the Super Bowl, but the monoculture is still a myth
SUMMARY: Super Bowl viewership isn't faltering in the same way broadcast, cable and awards shows are. But do we really need mass consumption of the same cultural work? Or just smart and connected consumption?

TITLE: Grover the Muppet says he's a reporter. Not for long, joke his beleaguered peers
SUMMARY: "As a news reporter ... I am confident to report that you are so special and amazing," Grover tweeted. Some responded with jokes about him getting laid off, a common occurrence in today's media world.

TITLE: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin is discharged from hospital, resuming full duties
SUMMARY: Austin, 70, has had ongoing health issues since undergoing surgery in December to treat prostate cancer. In January, Austin was hospitalized for two weeks after he experienced surgery complications.

TITLE: Pakistan heads toward a coalition government
SUMMARY: The announcement of plans for a coalition government ends the uncertainty since last week when no party won a simple majority in parliamentary elections.

TITLE: Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas impeached by House Republicans
SUMMARY: Mayorkas becomes the first cabinet secretary to be impeached since 1876. The Democratic-controlled Senate is expected to leave Mayorkas in office.

TITLE: Democrat Suozzi wins special election to replace Santos in New York
SUMMARY: Tom Suozzi will replace ousted Rep. George Santos in a critical swing district. The Democrat's win narrows the already razor-thin majority for Republicans in the House.

TITLE: Pakistan party nominates Shehbaz Sharif as prime minister, ending deadlock
SUMMARY: The move to reappoint Shehbaz Sharif as prime minister is a likely blow to millions of Pakistanis who voted in last week's elections for independents backed by the country's popular leader Imran Khan.

TITLE: A radio station is now playing Beyoncé's country song after an outcry from fans
SUMMARY: A fan said he emailed KYKC in Oklahoma and was told they don't play Beyoncé, as it is a country radio station. The station claims they did not yet have access to the song.

TITLE: 5 takeaways from Democrats flipping George Santos' House seat in New York
SUMMARY: Tuesday's special election was a sort of test for Republicans' and Democrats' campaign messaging in 2024, particularly around immigration and abortion.

TITLE: Recent gaffes by Biden and Trump may be signs of normal aging – or may be nothing
SUMMARY: President Biden and former President Trump have both experienced public memory lapses. But brain experts say such slips, on their own, are not a cause for concern.

TITLE: Catholic Church works to explain what same-sex blessings are and are not
SUMMARY: Now that Pope Francis has OK'd priests blessing same-sex couples, LGBTQ+ Catholics are figuring out how to ask for these blessings and whether they want them.

TITLE: The way a dying baby girl was cared for in 1980 helped shape her approach to nursing
SUMMARY: More than 40 years ago, when JoAnne Foley was a neonatal nurse, a baby was born with a severe congenital disorder. Foley recalls the way her supervisor made the baby feel loved.

TITLE: What is Temu, and should you let your parents order from it?
SUMMARY: Temu aggressively markets "hot deals," such as a hooded button-up fleece jacket for $8.32. But some U.S. officials accuse Temu of unfair and/or unethical practices.

TITLE: A small fish is at the center of a big fight in the Chesapeake Bay
SUMMARY: Recreational fishermen and conservation groups worry overfishing for menhaden threatens the Chesapeake Bay. Industry says current data doesn't support shutting down the more than century-old fishery.

TITLE: Officer involved in Freddie Gray's death will oversee Baltimore police integrity unit
SUMMARY: Captain Alicia White's move to the Public Integrity Bureau went into effect on Feb. 11, officials say. She is one of the six officers involved in Freddie Gray's death, none of whom were convicted.

TITLE: Dating habits are changing — again. Here are 3 trends and tips for navigating them
SUMMARY: Technology, burnout and generational differences are creating new habits in the dating scene. Two dating coaches share advice on how to navigate them.

TITLE: We asked young Black voters about Biden and the Democrats. Here's what we learned
SUMMARY: Young Black voters were a key part of the coalition that sent Joe Biden to the White House in 2020. Yet recent polls suggest some of that support has eroded.

TITLE: Brumation and torpor: How animals survive cold snaps by playing dead-ish
SUMMARY: Social media was recently taken aback watching as alligators in freezing weather appeared to go into a deep sleep to stay alive. They're not alone. Iguanas and hummingbirds do it too.

TITLE: The Oakland As hire the first female primary play-by-play announcer in MLB history
SUMMARY: Jenny Cavnar will call most of the games during the 2024 season. She was the backup play-by-play announcer for the Colorado Rockies for 12 years and has five Emmys.

TITLE: A dance about gun violence is touring nationally with Alvin Ailey's company
SUMMARY: Choreographer Jamar Roberts created a piece about gun violence and police brutality when he found himself sleepless over the issue. It's touring now with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

TITLE: The CDC may be reconsidering its COVID isolation guidance
SUMMARY: The current guidance advises five days of isolation. Unnamed health officials have indicated that this guidance may soon go away, a move that troubles public health experts.

TITLE: Romantic advice (regardless of your relationship status)
SUMMARY: Valentine's Day is a time to think about love — no matter whether you're single, taken, confused or ready to mingle.

TITLE: Ukrainian military says it sank a Russian landing ship in the Black Sea
SUMMARY: Sinking the vessel would be another embarrassing blow for the Russian Black Sea fleet and a significant success for Ukraine 10 days before the second anniversary of Russia's full-scale invasion.

TITLE: Recent gaffes by Biden and Trump may be signs of normal aging — or may be nothing
SUMMARY: President Biden and former President Trump have both experienced public memory lapses. But brain experts say such slips, on their own, are not a cause for concern.

TITLE: The Oakland A's hire the first female primary play-by-play announcer in MLB history
SUMMARY: Jenny Cavnar will call most of the games during the 2024 season. She was the backup play-by-play announcer for the Colorado Rockies for 12 years and has five Emmys.

TITLE: Tai chi reduces blood pressure better than aerobic exercise, study finds
SUMMARY: The slow-moving Chinese martial art tai chi is known to increase flexibility and balance. Now, research suggests it's more effective at reducing blood pressure than more vigorous forms of exercise.

TITLE: House votes to impeach Mayorkas; Democrats flip George Santos' seat
SUMMARY: The House voted along party lines to impeach Homeland Security chief Alejandro Mayorkas. A Democrat won the New York special election to replace GOP Rep. George Santos.

TITLE: Gun violence killed them. Now, their voices will lobby Congress to do more using AI
SUMMARY: On the 6th anniversary of the mass shooting in Parkland, Fla., gun control advocates experiment with AI-generated audio messages of recreated voices of victims of gun violence pleading for change.

TITLE: So you think you know all about the plague?
SUMMARY: A case in Oregon is a rarity in the United States. It is not expected to spread. But  this ancient and deadly disease remains a threat around the world.

TITLE: In Greece, same-sex couples await a landmark parliamentary vote on marriage equality
SUMMARY: Greece's parliament is set to vote Thursday on same-sex marriage legislation that includes new parental rights for LGBTQ couples. The Greek Orthodox Church opposes same-sex marriage.

TITLE: It's a Leap Year. How will you be spending your extra day?
SUMMARY: Will you be celebrating a birthday on Feb. 29, or have other fun plans in the works? NPR wants to know how you'll be spending your leap day.

TITLE: Ukrainian soldiers' valentines arrive by 'train of love'
SUMMARY: Ukrainian soldiers on a break from the front lines meet up with their wives and girlfriends, who arrive on the so-called "train of love," where every day is Valentine's Day.

TITLE: Rafah was supposed to offer refuge. Now, the city waits for a possible Israeli attack
SUMMARY: Roughly 1.4 million Palestinians sheltering in Rafah are bracing for a potential Israeli assault, but hoping for a diplomatic breakthrough as negotiators work to secure a cease-fire.

TITLE: Remembering Bob Edwards, Peabody Award-winning broadcast journalist
SUMMARY: Edwards, who died Feb. 10, was the first and longest-serving host of NPR's Morning Edition, from the show's inception in 1979 until 2004. Originally broadcast in 1993 and 2004.

TITLE: Ukraine's military says it sank a Russian landing ship in the Black Sea
SUMMARY: Ukraine's military says it destroyed Russia's Caesar Kunikov ship off the coast of occupied Crimea, although Russia has so far not confirmed the incident.

TITLE: Ex-general Prabowo Subianto claims victory in Indonesia's presidential election
SUMMARY: Prabowo, who had been barred from entering the U.S. for two decades for alleged human rights abuses, has the backing of the current president.

TITLE: A man died from Alaskapox last month. Here's what we know about the virus
SUMMARY: The first known fatality was an elderly man who lived alone in a forested area and was immunocompromised. Scientists say there's no evidence of human-to-human transmission of the virus so far.

TITLE: Multiple people hit by gunfire in shooting at Kansas City Chiefs' Super Bowl rally
SUMMARY: Police said shots were fired near Union Station, the site of the Chiefs' Super Bowl victory rally in Kansas City, Mo. Two armed people were taken into custody, authorities said.

TITLE: 1 dead, up to 15 injured in shooting at Kansas City Chiefs' Super Bowl rally
SUMMARY: Police said shots were fired near Union Station, the site of the Chiefs' Super Bowl victory rally in Kansas City, Mo. Two armed people were taken into custody, authorities said.

TITLE: 1 dead, up to 21 injured in shooting at Kansas City Chiefs' Super Bowl rally
SUMMARY: Police said shots were fired near Union Station, the site of the Chiefs' Super Bowl victory rally in Kansas City, Mo. Three people were taken into custody, authorities said.

TITLE: 1 dead, up to 21 others injured in shooting at Kansas City Chiefs' Super Bowl rally
SUMMARY: Police said shots were fired near Union Station, the site of the Chiefs' Super Bowl victory rally in Kansas City, Mo. Three people were taken into custody, authorities said.

TITLE: 1 dead, at least 21 injured in shooting at Kansas City Chiefs' Super Bowl rally
SUMMARY: A local Tejano music DJ, and mother of two was killed in the shooting following the Chiefs' Super Bowl victory rally in Kansas City, Mo. Three people were taken into custody, authorities said.

TITLE: Maker of Tinder, Hinge sued over 'addictive' dating apps that put profits over love
SUMMARY: Match Group was sued on Wednesday for violating consumer protection laws for allegedly addicting dating app users through "predatory" practices that mislead people searching for romantic partners.

TITLE: Americans who live alone report depression at higher rates, but social support helps

SUMMARY: One person was killed and at least 21 others were injured in the attack outside Union Station in Kansas City.

TITLE: Special counsel asks Supreme Court to move quickly on the Trump immunity case
SUMMARY: Special counsel Jack Smith urged the U.S. Supreme Court on Wednesday to let former President Donald Trump's 2020 election interference case proceed to trial without further delay.

TITLE: Israeli forces enter main hospital in southern Gaza after prolonged standoff
SUMMARY: The raid came a day after the army sought to evacuate thousands of displaced people who had taken shelter at the Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis.

TITLE: Empty office buildings litter U.S. cities. What happens next is up for debate
SUMMARY: A recent study calculated that about a fifth of U.S. office space was vacant at the end of last year. What is the fate of all this empty real estate?

TITLE: Chicago will drop controversial ShotSpotter gunfire detection system
SUMMARY: Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson followed through on his campaign promise by announcing the city won't renew the contract for the system, which critics have called ineffective and costly.

TITLE: Trump is rattling Europe. Now Harris is going there to try to calm nervous allies
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris is making a major address on Friday at the Munich Security Conference. But European leaders are alarmed at the U.S. failure to keep its promise to continue to back Ukraine.

TITLE: Russia is developing nuclear capability to threaten satellites, source says
SUMMARY: The full extent of the threat is unclear as the details remain classified. National security adviser Jake Sullivan is expected to brief a small group of lawmakers on Thursday.

TITLE: Japan's space agency says it may now have clues about the origins of the moon
SUMMARY: An unmanned lunar spacecraft has captured and transmitted data analyzing lunar rocks, an achievement that could help provide clues about the origin of the moon, a Japan space agency official said

TITLE: Hurricane Idalia shows nature may provide the best shoreline protection
SUMMARY: Researchers at the University of Florida found that nature-based "living shoreline" projects significantly reduced wave energy and were largely undamaged during Hurricane Idalia last year.

TITLE: Rafah was supposed to offer refuge. Now, the city waits for a possible Israeli attack
SUMMARY: Roughly 1.4 million Palestinians sheltering in Rafah are bracing for a potential Israeli assault, but hoping for a diplomatic breakthrough as negotiators work to secure a cease-fire.

TITLE: It's a Leap Year. How will you be spending your extra day?
SUMMARY: Will you be celebrating a birthday on Feb. 29, or have other fun plans in the works? NPR wants to know how you'll be spending your leap day.

TITLE: 1 killed at Chiefs parade shooting; Russia is developing a space-based nuclear device
SUMMARY: A shooting at the Kansas City Chiefs Super Bowl parade killed one woman and injured at least 21 others, including children. Russia is developing a nuclear capability that could target satelites.

TITLE: Israeli forces enter main hospital in southern Gaza after prolonged standoff
SUMMARY: The raid came a day after the army sought to evacuate thousands of displaced people who had taken shelter at the Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis.

TITLE: Could vacant office spaces across the U.S. be the solution to a national problem?
SUMMARY: A recent study calculated that about a fifth of U.S. office space was vacant at the end of last year. What is the fate of all this empty real estate?

TITLE: Abortion pills that patients got via telehealth and the mail are safe, study finds
SUMMARY: The study looks at 6,000 patients who got abortion pills after an online appointment. It found that 99.7% of those abortions were not followed by any serious adverse events.

TITLE: Trump's New York hush money trial will start March 25
SUMMARY: The judge in the hush money case against Donald Trump has rejected the former president's attempt to dismiss the charges, and a jury trial will begin as originally scheduled on March 25.

TITLE: Latino Democrats launch "Our Lucha" war room using Spanglish to combat GOP
SUMMARY: The campaign arm of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus is calling the new effort "Our Lucha War Room," or their fight for Latinos and boosting their  representation in Congress.

TITLE: DOJ watchdog finds 187 inmate suicides in federal prisons over 8-year period
SUMMARY: The Justice Department watchdog found 344 inmate deaths in federal prison from suicide, homicide or accident between 2014 and 2021. The majority of those deaths were suicides.

TITLE: Photos: Shooting in Kansas City after Chiefs' victory parade
SUMMARY: One person was killed and at least 21 others were injured in the attack outside Union Station in Kansas City.

TITLE: How NYC is coping with 175,000 migrants from the Southern border
SUMMARY: <em>New York Times

TITLE: Ebola vaccine cuts death rates in half — even if it's given after infection
SUMMARY: Ebola is one of the most feared infectious diseases, with more than half of those infected dying. A vaccine has now been shown to cut that mortality rate in half.

TITLE: Americans who live alone report depression at higher rates, but social support helps
SUMMARY: The number of people living alone in the U.S. jumped to nearly 38 million. A new study shows people who live alone are more likely to report depression if they didn't have other social supports.

TITLE: Strikes along Israel's border with Lebanon are again fueling fears of a widening war
SUMMARY: A series of deadly strikes on Wednesday and Thursday underscored the risk that daily cross-border skirmishes could quickly escalate and turn the war in Gaza into a broader regional conflict.

TITLE: How NYC is coping with 175,000 migrants from the Southern border
SUMMARY: <em>New York Times

TITLE: Russia is working on a weapon to destroy satellites but has not deployed one yet
SUMMARY: The White House says there's no immediate threat to safety. National security adviser Jake Sullivan is briefing a small group of lawmakers on Thursday.

TITLE: The Romance Between The American Right, Russia And Putin
SUMMARY:
For half a century, during the Cold War, every U-S president painted Russia as the dominant threat. America's ideological opposite, a hostile and nuclear-armed power. Ronald Reagan went so far as to call the Soviet Union an Evil Empire.

So the events of recent days have been noteworthy. On top of a holdup of U-S aid for Ukraine, former President Trump said he might NOT come to the defense of a NATO ally who hadn't spent enough on defense.

And Tucker Carlson, the erstwhile Fox news host, flew to Moscow to sit down with Vladimir Putin for more than two hours of mostly softball questions.

Afterward, he pronounced Putin "impressive" on stage at the World Government Summit.

So what gives? Why the romance between the American right and Russia?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: FBI informant charged with lying about Joe and Hunter Biden's ties to Ukrainian firm
SUMMARY: Alexander Smirnov falsely told FBI agents in 2020 that executives associated with the Ukrainian energy company Burisma paid Hunter and Joe Biden $5 million each in 2015 or 2016, prosecutors said.

TITLE: Greece legalizes same-sex marriage despite church opposition
SUMMARY: Greece on Thursday became the first Orthodox Christian country to legalize same-sex civil marriage, despite opposition from the influential, socially conservative Greek Church.

TITLE: Latino Democrats launch 'Our Lucha' war room using Spanglish to combat GOP
SUMMARY: The campaign arm of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus is calling the new effort "Our Lucha War Room," or their fight for Latinos and boosting their representation in Congress.

TITLE: Caitlin Clark — a 'tsunami of impact and influence' — breaks the NCAA scoring record
SUMMARY: The Iowa senior now holds the NCAA women's points record. Here's how she got this far — and what it means for the sport.

TITLE: Montana GOP lawmaker quickly drops Senate bid, citing Trump's endorsement of opponent
SUMMARY: Rep. Matt Rosendale has ended his bid for the Senate less than a week after he launched his campaign. He said in a statement he lacks resources and that the "hill was just too steep to climb."

TITLE: Reduce, reuse, redirect outrage: How plastic makers used recycling as a fig leaf
SUMMARY: Recycling "does not solve the solid waste problem," the head of a plastics trade group said in 1989, around the time the industry was launching its recycling campaign.

TITLE: Eyes on the road: Automated speed cameras get a fresh look as traffic deaths mount
SUMMARY: New laws will allow automated speed cameras in places where they've long been banned. Advocates say they can save lives, but critics argue they're a financial burden on those least able to pay.

TITLE: Toby Keith's 'Courtesy of the Red, White and Blue' lives on in MAGA country
SUMMARY: Keith's death shined a new spotlight on his music, particularly political anthem "Courtesy of the Red, White and Blue," best known for its lyric: "We'll put a boot in your ass, it's the American way."

TITLE: Lawsuit accusing NRA of lavish misspending now heads to jury
SUMMARY: The case accused leaders of the National Rifle Association of corruption and misspending and now heads to the jury, which is expected to begin deliberations Friday.

TITLE: Migrating animals undergo perilous journeys every year. Humans make it more dangerous
SUMMARY:
Every year, billions of animals across the globe embark on journeys. They fly, crawl, walk or slither – often across thousands of miles of land or water – to find better food, more agreeable weather or a place to breed. Think monarch butterflies, penguins, wild Pacific salmon. These species are crucial to the world as we know it. But until this week, there has never been an official assessment of the world's migratory animals.

So today on the show, correspondent Nate Rott shares the first-ever report on state of the world's migratory animals – the threats facing them and what can be done to help.

Are you afraid of needles or shots? Send us a voice memo with your story at shortwave@npr.org. We'd love to hear about it for an upcoming episode.

TITLE: Alexei Navalny has died in prison at 47, Moscow says
SUMMARY: The Federal Prison Service said in a statement that Navalny felt unwell after a walk on Friday and lost consciousness. The politician's team says it has received no confirmation of his death so far.

TITLE: Alexei Navalny, Russian politician who opposed Putin to the end, has died in prison
SUMMARY: The Federal Prison Service said in a statement that Navalny felt unwell after a walk on Friday and lost consciousness. The politician's team says it has received no confirmation of his death so far.

TITLE: Alexei Navalny has died in prison; Israeli troops raid Gaza's Nasser Hospital
SUMMARY: Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny died in prison after losing consciousness after a walk, according to the country's prison service. Israeli troops take over Southern Gaza's largest hospital.

TITLE: Jake Sullivan says the U.S. is engaging with allies, and Russia, on the space threat
SUMMARY: National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan spoke to NPR's <em>Morning Edition

TITLE: Tech giants pledge action against deceptive AI in elections
SUMMARY: Fears over how AI could be used to mislead voters are escalating in a year that will see hundreds of millions of people around the world cast ballots. As a result, tech giants are pledging action.

TITLE: Women are breaking Brazil's 'bate bola' carnival mold
SUMMARY: Women are taking their rightful place in Rio's "carnival of the streets" — the "<em>bate-bolas,

TITLE: Caitlin Clark's scoring record reveals legacies of Lynette Woodard and Pearl Moore
SUMMARY: The scoring records of two Black American college basketball stars from the 1970s and 1980s are overlooked by the NCAA as Caitlin Clark takes the mantle as women's scoring champion.

TITLE: Navalny's legacy: His ceaseless crusade against Putin and corruption
SUMMARY: In a sign of Navalny's ability to inspire the public, in 2017 his followers chanted words in Putin's hometown that are among the most dangerous to utter in their country: "Russia without Putin."

TITLE: The world reacts to the death of Navalny, a top critic of Russian President Putin
SUMMARY: The international reaction to the death of the prominent Russian opposition leader was swift, with many blaming the Kremlin.

TITLE: How ageism against Biden and Trump puts older folks at risk
SUMMARY: Recently, conversation about the age of the 2024 presidential candidates has risen to a fever pitch. That's the sign of a deeper problem with how our culture views aging.

TITLE: Photos: See Russian anti-corruption leader Alexei Navalny's life in pictures
SUMMARY: The Russian opposition leader was a prominent critic of Vladimir Putin. He was known for organizing nationwide protests against election fraud and government corruption.

TITLE: In Navalny's final hours of freedom, he was calm, funny and watching 'Rick and Morty'
SUMMARY: Russian authorities announced on Friday that opposition leader Alexei Navalny had died in a remote Russian prison. Navalny was imprisoned after returning to Russia in 2021.

TITLE: Alexei Navalny is the latest Putin critic to die in suspicious circumstances
SUMMARY: The death of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny in prison was shocking, but hardly surprising. It follows a long line of fallen critics and opponents of Russian leader Vladimir Putin.

TITLE: After months of speculation, Sen. Joe Manchin will not run for president in 2024
SUMMARY: After speculation the powerful centrist Democrat would run third-party, Manchin announced Friday he would not be running for president in the 2024 election. But he did not endorse a candidate.

TITLE: As the world mourns Navalny, leaders and supporters point at Russia's government
SUMMARY: The international reaction to the death of the prominent Russian opposition leader was swift, with many blaming the Kremlin.

TITLE: Trump ordered to pay $350 million for fraudulent business practices in New York
SUMMARY: A New York judge has ordered former President Donald Trump and executives at the Trump Organization to pay nearly $364 million.

TITLE: How the ex-FBI informant charged with lying is tied to the Biden impeachment inquiry
SUMMARY: Alexander Smirnov has been indicted for making false statements to the FBI — claims that House Republicans have used in their probe of President Biden.

TITLE: Women are breaking Brazil's 'bate-bola' Carnival mold
SUMMARY: Women are taking their rightful place in Rio's "Carnival of the streets" — the "<em>bate-bolas,

TITLE: Trump ordered to pay nearly $355M for fraudulent business practices in New York
SUMMARY: A New York judge has ordered former President Donald Trump and executives at the Trump Organization to pay nearly $364 million.

TITLE: Biden visits East Palestine a year after a train derailment changed the Ohio town
SUMMARY: Biden had promised to visit soon after the derailment. He has faced criticism from some residents and from former President Donald Trump, who made a trip to the community shortly after the disaster.

TITLE: Searching for the remains of hostages, Israeli forces raid another Gaza hospital
SUMMARY: Israeli forces have found no hostage remains so far, but their raid has essentially rendered the largest hospital in Gaza's Khan Younis nonfunctional.

TITLE: Trump ordered to pay over $355M for fraudulent business practices in New York
SUMMARY: A New York judge has ordered former President Donald Trump and executives at the Trump Organization to pay over $364 million.

TITLE: Ukraine withdrawing from Avdiivka, where outnumbered defenders held out for 4 months
SUMMARY: In a short statement posted on Facebook early Saturday, a Ukrainian commander said he had made the decision to avoid encirclement by Russian forces and "preserve the lives and health of servicemen."

TITLE: An explosion at a Virginia home kills 1 firefighter and injures 11
SUMMARY: An explosion in a Washington, D.C., suburb leveled a home where firefighters were investigating a gas leak. One firefighter was killed and nine other firefighters injured. Two civilians were injured.

TITLE: Autoworkers threaten to strike again at Ford's huge Kentucky truck plant
SUMMARY: The United Auto Workers union said Friday that nearly 9,000 workers at the Kentucky Truck Plant in Louisville will strike on Feb. 23 if a local contract dispute is not resolved.

TITLE: In wake of mass shootings, some parents hesitate bringing their kids to big events
SUMMARY: About half those injured in the Kansas City Super Bowl parade shooting were children. With such incidents continuing to happen, some parents now think twice about bringing kids to big, crowded events.

TITLE: The hottest trend in U.S. cities? Changing zoning rules to allow more housing
SUMMARY: As Americans struggle to find affordable housing, cities are realizing their own rules have made it too hard and expensive to build the homes they need. Now, some cities are trying to change that.

TITLE: With Palestinian laborers shut out of Israel, Indian workers line up for jobs there
SUMMARY: Israel is recruiting skilled laborers from India after suspending work permits for most Palestinian workers following the Oct. 7 attack on Israel by Hamas-backed militants.

TITLE: Nikki Haley's latest target on the campaign trail? Kamala Harris
SUMMARY: Republican presidential hopeful Nikki Haley has recently been directing attacks at Vice President Kamala Harris as she highlights concerns about President Biden's age.

TITLE: Thousands of vets fell victim to a bait-and-switch...by the VA? Lawmakers want a fix
SUMMARY: Lawmakers grilled the head of the VA home loan program this week about a self-inflicted error with the department's COVID forbearance program that left thousands of veterans in danger of foreclosure.

TITLE: Alexei Navalny's team confirms his death. His mother is searching for his body
SUMMARY: Alexei Navalny's spokesperson confirmed Saturday that the Russian opposition leader had died at a remote Arctic penal colony and said he was "murdered," but it is unclear where his body is.

TITLE: Harris says 'there is only Plan A' for Ukraine aid. Zelenskyy says he's counting on it
SUMMARY: Ukraine aid is stalled in the U.S. House of Representatives. Vice President Harris said there's no other option for helping Ukraine push back against Russia's invasion.

TITLE: FDA approves first cell therapy to treat aggressive forms of melanoma
SUMMARY: Amtagvi is intended to help patients with melanoma that cannot be removed with surgery or has spread to other parts of the body.

TITLE: Ex-FBI official gets over 2 years in prison for receiving $225,000 tied to Albania
SUMMARY: Charles McGonigal, a former high-ranking FBI counterintelligence official, was sentenced for taking hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash from a businessman with ties to the Albanian government.

TITLE: Leaking underground propane tank found at Virginia home before deadly house explosion
SUMMARY: An explosion in a Washington, D.C., suburb leveled a home where firefighters were investigating a gas leak. One firefighter was killed and nine other firefighters injured. Two civilians were injured.

TITLE: Lefty Driesell, coach who put Maryland on college basketball's map, dies at 92
SUMMARY: The Hall of Famer whose folksy drawl belied a fiery on-court demeanor was the first coach to win more than 100 games at four NCAA Division I schools.

TITLE: Worries grow over fate of Palestinian doctor after Israeli troops raid Gaza hospital
SUMMARY: The last messages sent by Dr. Khaled al-Serr were on Thursday night from a Gaza hospital raided by the Israeli military. Colleagues fear he has been detained by the Israeli military.

TITLE: The CDC investigates a multistate E. coli outbreak linked to raw cheddar cheese
SUMMARY: Health officials reported 10 cases of <em>E. coli

TITLE: Ukraine withdraws from Avdiivka, in Russia's first major battlefield win in months
SUMMARY: It's Russia's first significant battlefield win since last May. The White House said Ukrainian soldiers pulled out because they had "dwindling supplies as a result of congressional inaction."

TITLE: U.N. court to hold hearings on legality of the occupation of Palestinian-claimed lands
SUMMARY: The United Nations' highest court opens historic hearings Monday into the legality of Israel's 57-year occupation of lands sought for a Palestinian state.

TITLE: Millions of women are 'under-muscled'. These foods help build strength
SUMMARY: We start to lose muscle in our 30s, and the loss accelerates with age, putting us at risk of frailty later in life. But what you eat — specifically how much protein — is a big part of the solution.

TITLE: Chinese electric carmakers are taking on Europeans on their own turf — and succeeding
SUMMARY: Chinese automakers are winning over European consumers as part of a big push to enter markets abroad. Their success has sparked alarm among rival companies and lawmakers.

TITLE: Generations after its heyday, isolationism is alive and kicking up controversy
SUMMARY: For a time, the phrase "America First" seemed an artifact of the prewar world. But the idea that the U.S. would do better by holding the rest of the world at arm's length never entirely disappeared.

TITLE: Over 400 detained in Russia as country mourns the death of Alexei Navalny
SUMMARY: Over 400 people were detained in Russia while paying tribute to opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who died at a remote Arctic penal colony, a prominent rights group reported.

TITLE: Oscar-nommed doc: A 13-year-old and her dad demand justice after she is raped
SUMMARY: In "To Kill a Tiger," director Nisha Pahuja follows the case of a girl who is gang-raped in her Indian village. The villagers say she should marry one of the rapists.

TITLE: MLS will open its season this week with replacement referees after labor talks falter
SUMMARY: Major League Soccer said it would be turning to replacement refs, after members of the referees' union voted overwhelmingly against a new contract offer from the Professional Referee Organization.

TITLE: FDA approves a drug to treat severe food allergies, including milk, eggs and nuts
SUMMARY: Xolair is considered the first medication approved by the FDA that can help protect against severe allergic reactions brought on by accidental exposure to certain foods.

TITLE: The U.S. military says it struck a Houthi underwater vessel in the Red Sea
SUMMARY: U.S. Central Command said it was the first time the Iranian-backed rebel group had been observed using an uncrewed underwater vessel since starting a series of attacks in the region in October.

TITLE: Millions of women are 'under-muscled.' These foods help build strength
SUMMARY: We start to lose muscle in our 30s, and the loss accelerates with age, putting us at risk of frailty later in life. But what you eat — specifically how much protein — is a big part of the solution.

TITLE: Dozens of men killed in Papua New Guinea tribal violence, Australian media report
SUMMARY: Dozens of men were massacred in a major escalation of tribal violence in Papua New Guinea, Australian media reported. Police expected to find more dead bodies among the wounded who had escaped.

TITLE: Thousands rail against Mexico's president and ruling party in 'march for democracy'
SUMMARY: Thousands of demonstrators cloaked in pink marched through cities in Mexico and abroad on Sunday in what they called a "march for democracy" targeting the country's ruling party.

TITLE: 'Oppenheimer' wins 7 prizes, including best picture, at British Academy Film Awards
SUMMARY: Atom bomb epic <em>Oppenheimer

TITLE: Poland's new government deprograms its once far-right public media
SUMMARY: Under Poland's Law and Justice party, the country's public broadcaster was turned into a propaganda tool for the far-right government to use as it wished. That era has come to an end.

TITLE: In latest lunar landing trial, Intuitive Machines hopes to get U.S. back to the moon
SUMMARY: If successful, the uncrewed spacecraft would be the first U.S. lunar landing in more than 50 years, and would mean one giant leap for the commercial space sector.

TITLE: Near-record winds over the Northeast push passenger planes to speeds over 800 mph
SUMMARY: A couple of planes got a big push from a jet stream with winds clocking 265 mph at cruising altitude this weekend, the National Weather Service said.

TITLE: Dozens of men killed in Papua New Guinea tribal violence, police say
SUMMARY: At least 26 combatants and an unconfirmed number of bystanders were killed in a gunbattle between warring tribes in Papua New Guinea, police said Monday.

TITLE: Maui fire survivors struggle to find long-term housing, half a year after the blazes
SUMMARY: Thousands of people are still displaced and living in limbo 6 months after the wildfires on Maui. The disaster has deepened a housing crisis, and is taking a toll on fire survivors.

TITLE: Israeli settlers are guarding the West Bank. Palestinians say it's worsening violence
SUMMARY: In Hebron, many settlers have joined the ranks of the Israeli military. Palestinians and Israeli human rights activists say the result has been abuse and harassment.

TITLE: Russia takes Ukrainian town of Avdiivka; Texas builds military camp on Mexico border
SUMMARY: Russian forces now occupy Avdiivka, a strategically important town in eastern Ukraine. Texas is building a controversial state military base camp near the Mexico border.

TITLE: Widow of Alexei Navalny takes center stage in Russia's opposition
SUMMARY: Yulia Navalnaya appeared on her late husband's YouTube channel in a forceful challenge to Russian President Vladimir Putin, accusing him of murder. Navalnaya says she will carry on her husband's work.

TITLE: Photos: Border tensions rise as Israel confirms Rafah as its next military target
SUMMARY: This past week, despite growing tensions at the borders, Israel announced a plan to move forward into the southern Gaza city of Rafah. Also, Israeli airstrikes killed many in Lebanon.

TITLE: What to know about the debut of Trump's $399 golden, high-top sneakers
SUMMARY: The announcement came one day after a New York judge ordered Trump and the Trump Organization to pay nearly $355 million as part of a civil fraud case.

TITLE: Cougar attacks five mountain bikers on a trail in Washington state
SUMMARY: Cougars are solitary  animals rarely seen in the wild, but on Saturday, five people were attacked by one on a trail in Washington. No one died, but at least one of the cyclists was hospitalized.

TITLE: In historians' Presidents Day survey, Biden vs. Trump is not a close call
SUMMARY: A survey of historians and presidential experts ranks President Biden in 14th place all-time, just ahead of Woodrow Wilson and Ronald Reagan. Former President Donald Trump came in last.

TITLE: What Navalny's Death Means For The Russian Opposition
SUMMARY:
Much of the world has spent the weekend mourning Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny. And asking why he chose to return to Russia, after he'd been poisoned, and when it was clear he was in danger.

Filmmaker Daniel Roher, who interviewed Navalny for the Oscar-winning documentary "Navalny," says the Russian opposition leader was an incredibly optimistic and certain about himself and his mission. And that Navalny believed he could usher in a brighter future for Russia.

So what happens to that future now? Aleksei Miniailo an opposition activist and researcher in Moscow weighs in on how the Russian opposition sustains its movement after the death of its most prominent figure.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: Putin's grip on power is weaker than it appears, an opposition activist tells NPR
SUMMARY: If the Russian president continues to burn through his reserves of oil and gas money, ordinary people will become a threat to his power, according to one outspoken activist.

TITLE: Bayer makes a deal on popular contraceptive with Mark Cuban's online pharmacy
SUMMARY: Bayer is adding two of its name-brand drugs to the roster of Cost Plus Drugs: the birth control pill Yaz and the menopause treatment Climara.

TITLE: Putin's regime is 'running out of fuel,' a Russian opposition activist tells NPR
SUMMARY: If the Russian president continues to burn through his reserves of oil and gas money, ordinary people will become a threat to his power, according to one outspoken activist.

TITLE: Wife of assassinated Haitian president is indicted in his killing
SUMMARY: A judge in Haiti probing the 2021 assassination of President Jovenel Moïse indicted his widow, Martine Moïse, ex-prime minister Claude Joseph and the ex-chief of Haiti's National Police, Léon Charles.

TITLE: Capital One is acquiring Discover in a deal worth $35 billion
SUMMARY: The companies are teaming up, in part, to expand their payment network. Discover is the smallest of the four U.S.-based payment networks, which also include Visa, American Express and Mastercard.

TITLE: WikiLeaks founder Assange starts final legal battle to avoid extradition to U.S.
SUMMARY: Julian Assange's lawyers will begin their final U.K. legal challenge on Tuesday to stop the WikiLeaks founder from being sent to the United States to face spying charges.

TITLE: How far can cities go to clear homeless camps? The U.S. Supreme Court will decide
SUMMARY: Lower courts have said it's unconstitutional to punish people for sleeping outside if no shelter is available. Cities say these rulings have paralyzed their efforts to manage growing tent encampments.

TITLE: Indian courts can't prosecute non-Indian drug suspects. Tribes say it's a problem
SUMMARY: As the fentanyl crisis ravages Native American communities, some of their leaders want Indian police and courts to go after non-tribal dealers. But they can't without getting permission from Congress.

TITLE: In Philadelphia's Kensington neighborhood, heroin is far from 'chic'
SUMMARY: A young poet and writer who lost his father to opioid addiction says there's nothing cool about what the drugs did to his dad. So why are peers trying to look like emaciated people with addiction?

TITLE: N.Y.'s crusading attorney general tackles big targets: Trump, Cuomo and now the NRA
SUMMARY: New York Attorney General Letitia James has built a reputation targeting powerful national figures. Critics say her lawsuits are politically motivated, but she keeps winning in court.

TITLE: Assange starts last fight against U.S. extradition; Egypt builds wall near Gaza border
SUMMARY: WikiLeaks founder Assange's latest battle to avoid extradition to U.S. Egypt builds buffer in anticipation of a Palestinian refugee spillover. Louisiana's legislature begins special session on crime.

TITLE: Ukrainian caregivers in Italy feel effects of war from afar
SUMMARY: Photographer Chiara Negrello documented Ukrainian caregivers in Italy as they try to stay connected to family back home during the ongoing war.

TITLE: The U.S. has again vetoed a UN resolution demanding an immediate cease-fire in Gaza
SUMMARY: Tuesday's vote marked the third U.S. veto of a Security Council resolution demanding a cease-fire in Gaza. The Arab nations behind the plan hoped to show broad support for ending the Israel-Hamas war.

TITLE: The U.S. has again vetoed a U.N. resolution demanding an immediate cease-fire in Gaza
SUMMARY: Tuesday's vote marked the third U.S. veto of a Security Council resolution demanding a cease-fire in Gaza. The Arab nations behind the plan hoped to show broad support for ending the Israel-Hamas war.

TITLE: Tribal courts can't prosecute non-Native drug suspects. Tribes say it's a problem
SUMMARY: As the fentanyl crisis ravages Native American communities, some of their leaders want tribal police and courts to go after non-tribal dealers. But they can't without getting permission from Congress.

TITLE: Trump faces some half a billion dollars in legal penalties. How will he pay them?
SUMMARY: Donald Trump owes legal penalties totaling hundreds of millions of dollars in two civil cases recently decided in New York, raising questions about how he'll pay the amount.

TITLE: Global law enforcement effort cracks down on LockBit ransomware group
SUMMARY: Law enforcement officials from 11 countries have joined forces to disrupt the activities of LockBit, which is considered one of the most dreaded and most prolific team of cybercriminals.

TITLE: 'Something needs to change.' Woman denied abortion in South Carolina challenges ban
SUMMARY: The state law has been interpreted as banning abortion after six weeks of pregnancy. Planned Parenthood argues the ban is vague and shouldn't apply until at least three weeks later in pregnancy.

TITLE: Scientists have found a black hole so large it eats the equivalent of one sun per day
SUMMARY: With a mass 17 billion times larger than our sun, this black hole is the fastest-growing black hole ever recorded, Australian National University said.

TITLE: Israel ponders restricting access to one of Islam's holiest sites for Ramadan
SUMMARY: The proposal comes at a time when the war between Israel and Hamas has put Palestinians and Israelis on edge.

TITLE: Does Portugal Have The Answer To Stopping Drug Overdose Deaths?
SUMMARY:
Brian Mann covers the U-S opioid and fentanyl crisis for NPR. That means he talks to a lot of people struggling with addiction. Again and again, he's heard stories of people who have succumbed to their addiction — last year 112, 000 — more than ever in history.

But when Mann traveled to Portugal to report on that country's model for dealing with the opioid crisis, he heard a very different story. Overdose deaths in Portugal are extremely rare.

The country has taken a radically different approach to drugs – decriminalizing small amounts and publicly funding addiction services – including sites where people can use drugs like crack and heroin.

Portugal treats addiction as an illness rather than a crime. No one has to pay for addiction care, and no one scrambles to navigate a poorly regulated recovery system. Could Portugal's approach help the U-S fight its opioid epidemic?

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: Watch out, a dead satellite is falling back to Earth
SUMMARY: There's a one in a billion chance it could hit somebody on the head. Europe's space agency doesn't know exactly when or where it will land.

TITLE: Texas has spent over $148 million busing migrants to other parts of the country
SUMMARY: Since 2022, GOP Gov. Greg Abbott has bused over 102,000 migrants to predominantly Democratic-led cities. Supporters say the cost is necessary, but critics argue the program is expensive and inhumane.

TITLE: Ex-FBI source charged with Biden lies is tied to Russian intelligence, prosecutors say
SUMMARY: Federal prosecutors say that Alexander Smirnov admitted to authorities that "officials associated with Russian intelligence were involved in passing a story" about President Biden's son, Hunter.

TITLE: Alabama Supreme Court rules frozen embryos are 'children' under state law
SUMMARY: The Alabama Supreme Court has ruled that frozen embryos can be considered children under state law, a decision critics said could have sweeping implications for fertility treatment in the state.

TITLE: A Colorado man is dead after a pet Gila monster bite
SUMMARY: Christopher Ward was taken to a hospital shortly after being bitten by one of his two pet Gila monsters on Feb. 12. He was soon placed on life support and died Friday, Lakewood police said Tuesday.

TITLE: NASA is looking for people to test out its Mars simulator for a year
SUMMARY: The agency is accepting applicants for the second cohort of its Mars simulator mission. Participants will live and work from a 3D-printed, 1,700-square-foot facility at NASA's Houston space center.

TITLE: YouTube mom Ruby Franke apologizes at sentencing in child abuse case
SUMMARY: Franke told the judge that she would not argue for a shorter sentence before she stood to thank local police officers, doctors and social workers for being the "angels" who saved her children.

TITLE: The minty past and cloudy future of menthol cigarettes
SUMMARY: In the U.S., flavored cigarettes have been banned since 2009, with one glaring exception: menthols. That exception was supposed to go away in 2023, but the Biden administration quietly delayed the ban on menthols. Why? Well, an estimated 85 percent of Black smokers smoke menthols — and some (potentially suspect) polls have indicated that a ban on menthols would chill Biden's support among Black people. Of course, it's more complicated than that. The story of menthol cigarettes is tied up in policing, advertising, influencer-culture, and the weaponization of race and gender studies. Oh, and a real-life Black superhero named Mandrake the Magician.

TITLE: Death of Chilean poet Pablo Neruda should be reinvestigated, court rules
SUMMARY: The death of Nobel laureate Pablo Neruda days after Chile's 1973 military coup should be reinvestigated, an appeals court has ruled, saying new steps could help clarify what killed the poet.

TITLE: Beyoncé's 'Texas Hold 'Em' debuts at No. 1 on the country chart
SUMMARY: Beyoncé became the only other solo woman alongside Taylor Swift to achieve the feat with no accompanying artists, Billboard said.

TITLE: First there were AI chatbots. Now AI assistants can order Ubers and book vacations
SUMMARY: A new batch of AI-powered devices known as AI agents are all the rage in Silicon Valley. They're devices with a voice assistant that can complete real-world tasks for you.

TITLE: A grieving Palestinian, an Irish artist and the mural that brought them together
SUMMARY: Artist Emmalene Blake's mural on the wall of a Dublin pub became an iconic image of Gaza's grief. Then one day, she got an Instagram message from the Palestinian woman in the image.

TITLE: Supreme Court will hear challenge to EPA's 'good neighbor' rule that limits pollution
SUMMARY: The justices will consider whether to hit pause on a federal rule designed to reduce air pollution that drifts across states and can cause health troubles.

TITLE: Doctors didn't think much of her constant cough. A nurse did and changed her life
SUMMARY: After Julie developed a persistent cough, no one seemed to be able to identify the cause. Then, her unsung hero stepped in and saved her life.

TITLE: Student loan balances wiped for the first batch of borrowers in Biden's SAVE plan
SUMMARY: "It's moral hazard if you're only doing debt relief, but I believe we're balancing it out with accountability on colleges," says Education Secretary Miguel Cardona.

TITLE: Supreme Court weighs challenge to EPA rule; student loans wiped under SAVE plan
SUMMARY: The Supreme Court considers whether to pause an EPA rule meant to reduce pollution that drifts across states. The  Education Department canceled loans for nearly 153,000 borrowers on the SAVE plan.

TITLE: Doctors didn't think much of her cough. A nurse practitioner did and changed her life
SUMMARY: After Julie developed a persistent cough, no one seemed to be able to identify the cause. Then, her unsung hero stepped in and saved her life.

TITLE: How Alabama's ruling that frozen embryos are 'children' could impact IVF
SUMMARY: Frozen embryos are people and you can be held legally responsible if you destroy them, according to the Alabama Supreme Court. The decision could have wide-ranging implications for IVF clinics.

TITLE: A man sues Powerball after being told his $340M 'win' was a mistake
SUMMARY: In early January 2023, John Cheeks saw that the winning Powerball numbers online matched his lottery ticket. But when he tried to redeem the prize he was told it was a "mistake." Now, he's suing.

TITLE: Alabama's Supreme Court rules frozen embryos are 'children' under state law
SUMMARY: Fertility clinics in Alabama are contemplating next steps after the state Supreme Court ruled that frozen fertilized eggs are children — and discarding them would be a crime.

TITLE: E-bike head trauma soars as helmet use falls, study finds
SUMMARY: A new study shows that nearly 8,000 e-bike riders sought hospital care for head injuries in 2022. It's a huge increase and the majority of the injured riders were not wearing helmets.

TITLE: Boeing ousts the head of its troubled 737 Max program after quality control concerns
SUMMARY: The Boeing executive who oversaw the troubled 737 Max program, Ed Clark, has left the company. It's part of a broader management shakeup after a door plug panel blew off a jet in midair last month.

TITLE: Humanitarian crises abound. Why is the U.N. asking for less aid money than last year?
SUMMARY: "This is the first time that this has happened in recent years," said Martin Griffiths of the United Nations. about the reduced ask. Why in a time of greater need is the U.N. lowering its appeal?

TITLE: Wind Power Is Taking Over A West Virginia Coal Town. Will The Residents Embrace It?
SUMMARY:
Keyser, West Virginia, was once known for coal. But the jobs have been disappearing since the 1970s. First because of automation, then cheap natural gas. And now, the urgency to address climate change is one more pressure on this energy source that contributes to global warming.

Now the town, like so much of the country is attempting to transition to renewable energy. The country's first major climate policy, known as the Inflation Reduction Act, gave that transition a boost. It passed with the key vote of West Virginia's own Senator Democrat Joe Manchin.

Keyser represents a national shift in American energy production. And in a town that was defined by coal for generations, change can be difficult.
